The course covers: The pronunciation system, basic language patterns and essential vocabulary (words and phrases ) to achieve basic competence in listening, speaking, reading and writing skills; Study of dialogues and graded readings covering common and everyday practices aimed at providing some insight into Malay culture; Basic communication skills such as understanding and conveying simple messages and ideas through lessons on greetings and meeting people, telling of time, numerals, colours and nature; and Writing of postcards, e-mail and beginners' composition in the form of paragraphs. This course is tailored for new learners who do not have any prior knowledge of the Malay Language. A Placement test or interview is required for all Malaysian and Indonesian students, including those whose parent(s) are Malaysian or Indonesian.
 
LM9002 MALAY LANGUAGE LEVEL 2 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LM9001/HMM1 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LM9001
Mutually exclusive with: HMM2
This course includes: Use of an expanded list of `essential' vocabulary to facilitate learning of the four language skills, viz listening, speaking, reading and writing at the post-basic level; Malay grammar comprising use of affixes, sentence construction, parts of speech, proverbs, numeral classifiers and duplicated words; Reading and understanding of graded texts (dialogues, expository materials, advertisements, posters, etc) to develop comprehension skills; and Writing of simple formal and informal letters and elementary composition.
 
LM9003 MALAY LANGUAGE LEVEL 3 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LM9002 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LM9002
The course is a continuation of the current two levels, where more verb tenses in the past (simple past, imperfect) and future (simple future) are introduced, along with extensive vocabulary, grammar and expressions. This course focuses mainly on communication skills as it seeks to enhance students? competency in using the language. The course would provide a natural progression for students who wish to take their learning of the language to a higher level, especially for those who might need the language skills in the pursuits of their career. The course aims to provide students who have taken Malay Language level two or those with post-basic knowledge of the language, enhanced competency through wider exposure in using the language. These will be achieved by introducing students to enhanced grammar rules, wider vocabulary and more authentic learning.
 
LN9001 SWEDISH LANGUAGE LEVEL 1 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: No previous knowledge of the language
This 36-hour course aims to introduce the students to the Swedish language and provide them with the basic tools to communicate in that language. In addition, they will be introduced to various facets of scandinavian and Nordic culture, tradition and mentality of its people. Upon its completion, students will be able to express themselves in basic writing and speaking. They will also acquire basic reading and listening comprehension skills. Through a wide range of teaching materials, such as books, videos, web tutorials, articles and class debates, they will gain insight into Swedish life and culture. The language of instruction will initially be English with an increasing portion of Swedish. Towards the end of the course instruction and basic communications will be done in the target language.
 
LN9002 SWEDISH LANGUAGE LEVEL 2 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LN9001 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LN9001
This 48-hour course aims to build on language skills and cultural knowledge acquired either through the beginners' courses (LN9001) or equivalent skills attained in Sweden during their student exchange programmes. In addition, they will be introduced to more facets of Scandinavian and Nordic culture, tradition and mentality of its people. Upon its completion, students will have improved their reading, listening, writing and speaking skills. Through a wide range of teaching materials, such as books, videos, web tutorials, articles, group and paired work and class debates, they will gain further insight into Swedish life and culture. The language of instruction will be Swedish.
 
LR9001 RUSSIAN LANGUAGE LEVEL 1 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: No previous study of the language
Students will study the Russian alphabet, numbers, greetings, the politeness system, directions and places in the city, family members and professions. Throughout the course students will learn to use basic sentence structures to express present and future actions, describe themselves and their families, to ask and answer simple questions about people, weather, hobbies, and occupations. Grammatical topics introduced in LR9001 include pronouns, cases, verb conjunctions and question forms. Through the use of authentic texts and audio-visual materials the students' knowledge of the culture in Russia and Russian speaking countries will also be enhanced and expanded.
 
LS9001 SPANISH LANGUAGE LEVEL 1 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: No previous study of the language
Mutually exclusive with: HMS1
Designed for beginner students, this course in basic Spanish teaches the four skills in an integrated manner, using a communicative approach. Through the use of various written and audio-visual materials, students are trained to: provide personal information about themselves (name, address, nationality, occupation, studies, etc.), describe things and people (physical appearance and personality), locate things and people, express habitual actions at specific times, talk about festivities and special events, and express their hobbies and likes/dislikes. In addition to teaching the language, this course also aims at providing students with a global vision of the Spanish and Latin American culture from various perspectives (arts, music, festivals, gastronomy, etc.).
 
LS9002 SPANISH LANGUAGE LEVEL 2 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LS9001/HMS1 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LS9001
Mutually exclusive with: HMS2
ny student, who has successfully passed Spanish Language Level 1 (or equivalent), is eligible to take this course. It is a continuation of the previous level, where more verb tenses (present progressive and imperative) are introduced along with extensive vocabulary, grammar and expressions. This course mainly focuses on communication, where audio-visual materials play a more important role than written materials. Students are supposed to have a basic knowledge of the language in order to be able to cope with this level. Throughout the course, students will learn to use more complex grammar and structures to express actions such as asking for a favour, and giving commands and suggestions. They will also be able to create dialogues based on real-life situations (buying food and clothes, visiting the doctor, asking for and giving directions, ordering food at a restaurant). Issues about Hispanic culture will be used for listening comprehension and oral interaction to help students to increase their knowledge and gain a better understanding of this rich culture.
 
LS9003 SPANISH LANGUAGE LEVEL 3 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: HMS2/LS9002 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LS9002
Mutually exclusive with: HMS3
This Spanish course is a continuation of the previous two levels, where more verb tenses in the past (present perfect and simple past) and future (simple future) are introduced, along with extensive vocabulary, grammar and expressions. This course focuses mainly on communication, where audio-visual materials play a very important role and Spanish is the main language of instruction in the classroom. Throughout the course, students will learn to use more complex grammar and structures to express past, present and future actions, personal experiences and opinions on everyday issues. Through audio-visual and written materials, students will be exposed to Hispanic culture.
 
LS9004 SPANISH LANGUAGE LEVEL 4 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LS9003 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LS9003
Throughout the course, students will learn to use more complex grammatical structures to express present, past and future actions; to articulate and defend an opinion on various issues; to offer advice; to propose and suggest; to express wishes; to express agreement or disagreement; to express cause and consequence: etc. Through the use of more complex authentic texts and audio-visual materials, students' knowledge of the cultures of the Spanish-speaking world will also be enhanced and expanded.
 
LT9001 THAI LANGUAGE LEVEL 1 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: NO PREVIOUS STUDY OF THE LANGUAGE
Mutually exclusive with: HMT1
This course is designed for beginners with no previous knowledge of Thai. It will introduce students to the Thai alphabet, vowels and tones as well as help them to construct simple sentences using basic vocabulary and expressions related to everyday communicative situations. Through theme-based classroom activities, students will develop the four skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing. By the end of the course, students will be able to read, write and talk in Thai about simple topics related to their daily lives.
 
LT9002 THAI LANGUAGE LEVEL 2 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LT9001/HMT1 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LT9001
The various topics of daily communication introduced in Thai Level 1 will be expanded to include time, season, months of the year, travel, food, hospital visits etc. Building on the foundation of Thai Level 1, the instruction of Thai Level 2 will use theme-based classroom activities to allow, students of Thai Level 2 to further develop the four language skills of speaking, listening, writing and reading. In Thai Level 2, students will be given maximum opportunities to speak Thai in class using different methods for example; role-playing in different scenarios, doing a presentation about Thailand in a chosen topic of interest, to encourage active learning of the language.
 
LT9003 THAI LANGUAGE LEVEL 3 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LT9002/HMT2 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LT9002
Thai Language Level 3 (LT9003) is designed to advance the students' proficiency of the Thai Language. It is theme-based and includes communicative activities which help the students develop their skills in speaking, listening, writing and reading. The focus is on supporting students with their functional needs such as making or changing appointments, booking a reservation, communication with a doctor, etc. More advance sentence structures, grammatical rules, and usage of complicated words will be introduced. Thai culture will also be enriched through the context of langauge teaching.
 
LV9001 VIETNAMESE LANGUAGE LEVEL 1 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: No previous knowledge of the language
This course is designed for beginners with no previous knowledge of Vietnamese. It will develop the four skills of speaking, listening, writing and reading in Vietnamese in an integrated manner. Students will be introduced to the Vietnamese writing system as well as the pronunciation of alphabets and tones. Each lesson will cover pronunciation drills, conversational dialogues, and practice in vocabulary and grammar. Through a range of communicative activities, students will learn to carry out simple conversations on common topics related to their daily life. By the end of the course, they will develop some general understanding of the culture, customs and history of Vietnam.
 
LV9002 VIETNAMESE LANGUAGE LEVEL 2 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: LV9001 or Placement Test
Prerequisite: LV9001
Vietnamese Language Level 2 is the continuation of Vietnamese Language Level 1 and aims to further enhance student proficiency in four basic skills - listening, speaking, reading and writing, as well as increase their knowledge of Vietnamese culture. Texts about daily situations (e.g. making and canceling appointments, shopping, planning for traveling, renting a hotel room) with simple sentence structures will serve as a main source of learning materials.
 
LX9001 LATIN LANGUAGE LEVEL 1 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: No previous knowledge of the language
This 36-hour course aims to introduce the students to the Latin language and provide them with the basic tools to communicate in that language. In addition, they will be introduced to various Latin texts. Upon its completion, students will be able to express themselves in basic writing and speaking. They will also acquire basic reading and listening comprehension skills. This will be done trough a wide range of teaching materials, such as books, videos, web tutorials, articles and class debates. The language of instruction will initially be English with an increasing portion of Latin. Towards the end of the course instruction and basic communications will be done in the target language.
 
SP0001 WRITING & REASONING 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: Only for REP students
Mutually exclusive with: CY0001
The class will examine several major essay writers from the eighteenth to the twentieth century, which will work as models to learn about the art of essay writing. These texts will also engage students with historical and cultural issues on which to reflect. Students will also use two textbooks on writing and reasoning. The main textbook will be Writing to Learn and the secondary textbook will be Reasoning and Writing Well.
 
SP0037 FABLES, FOLKLORE, & LITERATURE 3.0 SOH
Prerequisite: Only for University Scholars Programme (USP) students.
Every society has its fables, myths, and folktales which are often transmitted orally. In this class, we will examine the phenomenon of folktales and folk culture from a comparative perspective. We begin with the `discovery' of folk culture in the late 17th & early 18th centuries by the brothers Grimm in Germany, and the brothers Perrault in France. What role did folk culture play in the birth of modernity, and why did these stories acquire such importance for scholars of the Enlightenment? Originally meant for adults, why did they become a vital part of children's education? Following this historical survey, we will examine the diverse perspectives of 20th century scholars: folk tales as archetypes, as reflections of the true character of a people; as the source of stock characters and plots; and as transformations of pagan myths or religious beliefs, or even historical events.
 
CH9201 FOOD CHEMISTRY 5.0 SPS
Not available to Programme: ACBS, ACC, ADM, AERO, ASEC, BCE, BCG, BEEC, BIE, BMS, BS, BUS, CBE, CE, CEE, CEEC, CHEM, CHIN, CS, CSC, CSEC, CVEC, ECMA, ECON, ECPP, ECPS, EEE, EEEC, EESS, ELAH, ELH, ENE, ENEC, ENG, HIST, IEEC, IEM, LMS, MAEC, MAT, MATH, ME(DES), ME(NULL), ME(RMS), MEEC(DES), MEEC(NULL), MEEC(RMS), MS, MS-2ndMaj/Spec(MSB), MTEC, PHIL, PHY, PPGA, PSLM, PSMA, PSY, SOC, SSM
Students will learn the chemical changes that take place during storage and processing of agricultural crops and food. Special attention will be paid to endogenous enzymes as present in the agricultural raw materials from which most foods are prepared. In addition, during the laboratory classes, students will learn the design of experiments and the analysis of the composition of food products. Food technologists should be aware of the importance of the various chemical and enzymatic processes and should be able to estimate their relevance. To practice this part of food chemistry, quantification of specific reactions will be practiced in computer cases.
 
CY1101 PRINCIPLES OF MODERN CHEMISTRY 3.0 SPS
Prerequisite: By permission/interviews only.
Mutually exclusive with: CBC113, CHEM1, CM1031, CM9001
Adopts a topical approach with a strong problem-solving orientation; a series of discussions covering modern day research as well as the impact of Chemistry will be used to illustrate the various fundamental concepts. The course introduces concepts of structures and properties of atoms and molecules, bonding, introductory thermodynamics, periodicity, isomerism and chemical reactions, the fundamentals of spectroscopy, electronic structure of atoms, periodic properties, ionic substances, covalent bonding, Lewis representations of molecules and ions, shapes of molecules, Lewis acids and bases, Bronsted acids and bases, hybridization and resonance, introduction to organic chemistry, chemistry of life and biological Chemistry. Enrollment will be limited to students who have gained entry into the scholar programme or by permission of the instructor.
 
CY1308 PHYSICS 3.0 SPS
Prerequisite: By Permission/Interview only. A level Physics
Mutually exclusive with: PAP211, PH1011, PH1012, PHYS1C
1. VECTORS 2. KINEMATICS 3. FORCES AND TORQUES 4. NEWTON?S LAWS OF MOTION 5. IMPULSE AND MOMENTUM 6. WORK AND ENERGY 7. THERMAL PHYSICS 8. ELECTRIC FIELD 9. MAGNETIC FIELD 10. MOTION OF CHARGED PARTICLES AND APPLICATIONS 11. CIRCUITS
 
CY1401 ALGORITHMS & COMPUTING I 2.0 SPS
Prerequisite: By Permission/Interview only
Mutually exclusive with: MH1400, MH1401
An introduction to the MATLAB environment. Variables and elementary computation. Graphing and visualization of functions and data. Programs. Basic programming structures: loops and conditional structures. Using MATLAB?s inbuilt functions. First ideas about algorithms. Exploration of a variety of applications in calculus, linear algebra, and discrete mathematics
 
CY1500 INTRODUCTORY RESEARCH METHODOLOGY 3.0 SPS
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be able to understand the fundamental principles of research and acquire the writing skills for research proposals. The students will be well prepared for the research attachment in laboratories.
 
CY1601 MATHEMATICS I 4.0 SPS
Prerequisite: By Permission/Interview only
Mutually exclusive with: MH1100, MH1101, MH1802, RE1001
Mathematics I serves as an introductory course for all Renaissance students in year 1. The course covers topics with emphasis on real valued functions of a real variable. These topics include: Limits, continuity, the Min/Max Theorem, and the Intermediate Value Theorem. Differentiability and differentiation rules. Critical points, the Mean Value Theorem and l'Hospital's rule. Inverse functions and derivatives of inverse functions. trigonometric, logarithm and exponential functions. The Riemann integral, the Fundamental Theorems of Calculus. Techniques of integration. Using integrals to calculate volume, mass, work, etc. Infinite sequences. Infinite series. Power series and radius of convergence. Taylor series and Taylor's formula. Ordinary Differential Equations and techniques for solving such. Through sample questions/exercises provided in the course material, the students can pick up fundamental principles and related concepts in engineering science applications.
 
SS0111 SPORT & CULTURE IN SINGAPORE: A SOCIOLOGICAL PERSPECTIVE 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS0101
To "think sociologically" about sport which are closely connected with the Singapore context. To examine the cultural foundations of sport, primarily from a Singapore perspective, but also considering international comparisons. To understand and critically evaluate social structures surrounding sport and culture by exploring concepts, theories, and studies (the body of knowledge) in the field of Sociology of Sport. To review diverse social phenomena relating to sport that are experienced (seeing, hearing, feeling, and doing) in the real world using "sociological imagination". To articulate and present ideas and knowledge relating to sport in Singapore.
 
SS1101 HUMAN ANATOMY & PHYSIOLOGY 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS1001
The objectives of this course are to learn about the structures and functions of the various organ systems within the human body and the role of these systems in physical performance, health and fitness.
 
SS1102 INTRODUCTION TO SPORT MANAGEMENT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: SS1003
This course introduces students to the field of sport management. It will examine theoretical foundations and concepts in sport management. In addition, students will examine current trends and development in the sport industry.
 
SS2101 FOUNDATIONS OF MOTOR BEHAVIOUR 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This introductory course introduces key concepts of motor control and learning, with a strong emphasis on experiential learning via practical experience of skills learning. The course comprises of components such as the degrees of freedom problem, theoretical paradigms, process of learning, and instructional strategies related to motor skills learning.
 
SS2102 INTRODUCTION TO SPORT BIOMECHANICS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This course introduces basic mechanical concepts, laboratory equipment and software to evaluate human movements: Linear and angular kinematics Linear and angular kinetics Equilibrium Fluid mechanics
 
SS2103 SPORT COACHING: FOUNDATIONS OF COACHING 3.0 SSM(NIE)
This course examines and applies practical sport coach pedagogy (learning theories and instructional models) to the sport environment. Issues related to effective coaching of young athletes will be addressed. In addition, pedagogical knowledge and application of the principles of motor skills? learning will be covered in this course.
 
SS2104 SPORT MARKETING & SPONSORSHIP 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: BU8541, SS3601
Not available to all Programme with: (Admyr 2004-2015)-Non Direct Entry, (Admyr 2004-2016)-Direct Entry
This course will introduce students to theories in the area of sport marketing and sponsorship. Students will learn various marketing theories and concepts which will allow them to appreciate the roles that marketing play in the industry. Market Segmentation and Consumer Behaviour Marketing Mix Sponsorship
 
SS2105 SEMINARS IN CURRENT ISSUES OF SPORT 1.0 SSM(NIE)
The course will cover topical sport science themes relevant to athletic performance, including doping and drug use and the role of sleep in sport performance. In relation to local athletes the effects of Ramadan on sport performance will be evaluated. From the sport management perspective, emerging topics related to sport marketing in social media and video games and the role and effectiveness of sport sponsorship will be evaluated. The organisation of major sporting events will also be discussed which is relevant to the recent major sport events (Formula 1, SEA Games) held in Singapore.
 
SS3001 STATISTICS, MEASUREMENT & EVALUATION 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2006 OR
ABA206
Mutually exclusive with: ABA206
This course is designed to provide students with basic concepts of measurement and evaluation in sport science and management. In addition, the course will focus on fundamental concepts of statistics and the use of computers for data analysis. Accordingly, the module introduces students to measurement issues in the sport science and management contexts, descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, the research process, the method of science, scientific investigation, the definition and evaluation of a research problem, hypothesis formation, and data collection.
 
SS3101 EXERCISE & SPORT PHYSIOLOGY II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS1006 OR
ABA106
A lecture/demonstration laboratory course is designed for the study of selected topics of exercise physiology. The principles of nutrition applied to sports performance and exercise will also be included. Emphasis will be placed on energy release and substrate utilization, energy metabolism during exercise, fluid intake and athletic performance, ergogenic aids, vitamins and minerals, the pre-game meal, sports anemia, nutritional considerations for the diabetic individual, lipid metabolism and coronary heart disease.
 
SS3103 SPORTS INJURIES II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2007 OR
ABA207
Physical activity is associated with multiple health benefits and enhanced quality of life. Sports participation across populations in the society is on the rise. Moreover, there has been a significant increase in number of adventure sports participants in recent times. The injury risks, patterns, principles of management and preventive strategies are different in each cohort. This course is designed to provide students with knowledge and the understanding of population-specific sports injuries and skills for primary management of injuries and preventive strategies.
 
SS3201 SPORT BIOMECHANICS II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2003 OR
ABA203
This course introduces participants to quantitative methods for determining mechanical parameters of movement, namely linear and angular kinematics and kinetics. Through laboratory work, participants will also learn about the operation of the equipment associated with the measuring techniques in sports biomechanics. Participants will be introduced to the theory governing these measurement techniques and studies that use of these measurement techniques. The aim of the course is to enable participants to effectively analyse movement, explain causes of observed effects and to correct errors in physical performance in sports through the use of these quantitative methods. Participants should have completed the mechanical and anatomical bases of human motion before enrolling for this course.
 
SS3301 EXERCISE & SPORT PSYCHOLOGY II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2001 OR
ABA201
This focus of this module is on psychology of sport and physical activity. The module is designed to provide students with an understanding of how psychological variables influence participation in sport and physical activity. The main focus is on the key motivational perspectives of exercise and sport but advance topics such as children in sport, burnout, psychology of injury and exercise psychology will also be covered.
 
SS3303 COACHING & LEARNING II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2004 OR
ABA204
This course following on the work undertaken in Coaching & Learning - Foundation 1 examines and applies practical sport coach pedagogy (learning theories and instructional models) to the sport environment. The course also considers pedagogical knowledge and application of the principles of motor skills? learning. This compulsory course critically examines and applies sport coach pedagogy (learning theories, preferences and instructional models as it relates to movement) to the sport environment.
 
SS3401 MOTOR LEARNING & CONTROL II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS2002 OR
ABA202
This course addresses behavioural aspects of human movement. Interpreting and intervening human performances from the psychomotor domain are the main foci of this course. Topics to be covered include practice conditions, feedback and skill acquisition, theories of motor learning, and measurements of motor performances.
 
SS3501 SOCIOLOGY OF SPORT II 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: SS1002 OR
ABA102
The theoretical contributions of Durkheim, Weber and the Marxists provide the backdrop for a study of the significance of sport within society during the twentieth and twenty first centuries. Themes and issues relating to the expansion of mass and elite sport are examined within local and international settings. Eastern and western perspectives of the significance of sport and physical activity are compared. Power relations and the accommodation of various groups within the sporting system are considered.
 
SS3601 SPORT MARKETING & SPONSORSHIP 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: BU8541, SS2104
Not available to all Programme with: (Admyr 2016-onwards)-Non Direct Entry
The course on sport marketing and sponsorship investigates the nature of sport products and the motivations of sport consumers. The sport consumer types are identified and their behaviour discussed. The essentials of marketing will be taught and related to sport. Students of the course will be given opportunity to work on a sport marketing project to appreciate and reinforce the complexity and dynamics of sport marketing. Sponsorship issues and strategies will also be covered including the relationship of sponsors to the sport, platforms and benefits of sport sponsorships.
 
SS3602 EVENT & FACILITIES MANAGEMENT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Sport is often presented through events which can be major meets like the World Cup or Olympics or regional and local events like a school meet. Students will through this course understand the importance of sport events and the decision making considerations of hosting an event. Opportunities will also be provided for students to experientially learn event management. Important to any sport event are the sport facilities which require strict compliance to specifications and maintenance. The concept of a multi-functional sport facility will also be explored. Risk management during events and in facilities management will be highlighted.
 
SS3603 HUMAN RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN SPORT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Mutually exclusive with: AE4008, MP4008
Managing human resources well is vital to any organisation. Students of this course will first begin to understand the different functions of human resource management such as recruiting, inducting, developing, and assessing personnel of the organisation. An important human resource asset to most sport organisation are volunteers. The motivation to participate in sport and the strategies of retaining sport volunteers will also be discussed and explored.
 
SS3604 LEGAL ASPECTS IN SPORT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Managing sport requires developing relationships between organisations, and between individuals representing the sport and organisation. Students of sport management must have an understanding of the legal aspects of these relationships and the roles and responsibilities of sport officials. Topics of this course include sources of law, duty of care of sport officials, the concept of tort and negligence, contracts, and others. Sport tribunals and its conduct will also be covered. Relevant case studies will be used for discussion and learning.
 
SS9001 CONDITIONING FOR PHYSICAL FITNESS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA901
Knowledge of aspects related to physical conditioning and weight training will be essential for students who plan to work in the fitness industry. The practical course on conditioning for physical fitness will equip our students with theoretical and practical skills to meet the needs of potential clients in fitness gyms and resorts. The course is 36 hours' duration.
 
SS9002 PRINCIPLES OF STRENGTH TRAINING 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA902
This module is structured to provide a concept and practice-based understanding of muscular fitness and conditioning on the following aspects: 1. Components of muscular fitness 2. Principles of muscular exercise and fitness a. Muscular exercise & fitness for health and sports performance b. Principles of strength training and muscular fitness 3. Muscular fitness training a. Types of resistance/strength training b. Familiarisation to equipment for strength training c. Strength training programmes d. Designing a personal muscular fitness programme e. Posture and lower back strength f. Exercise safety and injury prevention 4. Monitoring and assessment of muscular fitness
 
SS9101 BADMINTON 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: SS9111
The course aims to provide students with opportunities to acquire the knowledge, understanding and experience necessary to develop an appreciation of, and play, the sport of badminton. Students will be taught the essential skills necessary to play the sport.
 
SS9102 TENNIS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA918
This 36-hour course aims to impart the knowledge and competencies essential to having an informed understanding and appreciation of tennis. Students will be introduced to the basic skills necessary to play the game.
 
SS9103 SQUASH 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is designed to impart basic squash skills and knowledge of the game of squash to players at an introductory stage leading into intermediate levels. The emphasis of the course is on providing ample opportunities to play the game at a recreational as well as a competitive level. Also under consideration are the respective roles of player, referee and coach in creating a meaningful experience.
 
SS9104 BASKETBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is designed to provide students with the basic skills and knowledge to play and enjoy recreational basketball. Students will be taught on basic fundamental skills, rule/terminology, officiating, team offense/defense, and situational strategies.
 
SS9105 VOLLEYBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
1. To provide knowledge, understanding, and appreciation to the game of volleyball. 2. To develop satisfactory competency in basic skills such as body posture, forearm pass, serve and serve reception, overhead pass, attack, block, and game situational strategies. 3. To provide contents and methods required to teach volleyball at an introductory level. 4. To provide experience in game situations and officiating the game. 5. To be familiar with offensive and defensive strategies and able to execute them in game situations 6. To provide understanding of the teaching/coaching techniques 7. To lay a foundation for more advanced study/coaching in volleyball.
 
SS9106 NETBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
The course is designed to impart basic netball skills and knowledge. Participants will be given the opportunity to develop the basic footwork and ball skills, goal shooting skills, and study the principles of attacking/defending, as well as the application of these skills and game concepts/tactics in game play.
 
SS9107 TABLE TENNIS 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Introduction to the history, rules, and current trends in table tennis Concepts of grips, various racket surface(rubbers) and footwork Essential technical skills of table tennis - forehand and backhand drives, push, chops and service of various spins (top spin, under spin and side spin) Specialty shots and styles of play Singles and doubles strategies Different competition formats Use of software and video
 
SS9202 SOCCER 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Mutually exclusive with: ABA928
The 36-hour course aims to develop basic skills in soccer, and to provide an understanding and appreciation of the sport through an experiential process. Students will be introduced to the historical development and current trends in soccer, the technical aspects of soccer, strategies and tactics employed in the sport, and competition formats.
 
SS9203 HOCKEY 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Hockey as a game may seem ?strange and unfamiliar ?but actually it has many similarities to other sports. This course will enable students to learn the game of hockey in a fun manner. It pays particular attention to safety and will enable participants to enjoy the skills in a simple yet enjoyable manner. By the end of the course participants will be more aware of field hockey as a sport which can be enjoyed by all ages and all levels of ability.
 
SS9204 FLOORBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
Floorball is a young and fast growing game in Singapore and the world. The game is adapted from Ice Hockey. The game has grown quickly in Singapore as it is fast paced (high intensity), safe (using plastic based equipment) and easy to pick up. This course will enable students to learn the game of floorball in a fun and safe environment through a game centered approach. By the end of the course, the students will be able to appreciate and enjoy playing the game.
 
SS9205 RUGBY 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course aims to develop knowledge, understanding and playing competency in the various forms of rugby football namely, tag rugby, touch rugby and contact rugby. The basic techniques, tactics and strategies will be learnt and applied in practice and match situations and analysed from theoretical, practical and biomechanical perspectives.
 
SS9206 TCHOUKBALL 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
1. To provide knowledge, understanding, and appreciation to the game of tchoukball. 2. To develop satisfactory competency in basic skills such as passing, receiving passes, overarm and underarm shot, catching, individual and team defence, and game situational tactics. 3. To provide contents and methods required to teach tchoukball at an introductory level. 4. To provide experience in game situations and officiating a tchoukball game. 5. To be familiar with offensive and defensive strategies and able to execute them in game situations 6. To provide understanding of the teaching/coaching techniques 7. To lay a foundation for more advanced studying/coaching in tchoukball.
 
SS9302 DANCESPORT 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is structured to provide a concept (understanding different dance elements and terminology) and practice-based understanding of dance, specifically jazz and dance sport. Basic movement activities including locomotor movements, use of space, use of dynamics and original dance patterns. Social dances include Samba, Waltz and Cha-cha.
 
SS9303 INTRODUCTION TO HIP-HOP & ITS DANCES 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
How many times have you wondered- what exactly is Hip-Hop? Over this course, learners will be exposed to how the Hip-Hop culture we know of today, born in the mid-1970s in an impoverished section of New York City, found its way to the mass media and mainstream population and evolved into a multi-million dollar industry. Emphasis will be placed on learning about roots of Hip-Hop, particularly its dances. Participants will learn to dance to the rhythm of music and be introduced to some common moves popularized by prominent dance pioneers.
 
SS9304 INTRODUCTION TO MODERN JAZZ DANCE 3.0 SSM(NIE)
Prerequisite: Physically active.No injuries/medical conditions.
This course is structured to provide a concept and practice-based understanding of dance, specifically jazz. Together with theoretical and historical learning, participants will perform, respond and create. Movement activities include technique-based movements, locomotor movements, use of space and dynamics, and composition of dances. 1. Understanding the evolution of jazz dances and its historical contexts 2. Learning dance terminology and techniques 3. Improvising and creating dances 4. Appreciate dances by analyzing the forms and patterns 5. Understanding your body through dance 6. Create and perform dances individually and as a group
 
HN9010 SINGAPORE: IMAGINING THE NEXT 50 YEARS 3.0 SSS
Grade Type: Pass/Fail
Mutually exclusive with: AAL10C
This module aims to encourage undergraduates, who are our future leaders and citizens, to reflect on Singapore's post-independence history, imagine the kind of Singapore they would like to co-create for the future, and deliberate on what it takes to achieve the vision(s) they have for Singapore.
 
SP0012 INTERNATIONAL TRADE 3.0 SSS
Prerequisite: Only for University Scholars Programme (USP) students.
The course will cover the law of comparative advantage, the gains from trade, the Ricardian model, factor intensity and factor abundance, the Heckscher-Ohlin theory, factor-price equalization, standard and alternative trade theories, product differentiation and intra-industry trade, technological gaps and product cycles, trade and economic development, import substitution versus export orientation, tariff and non-tariff barriers, theory of effective protection, instruments and impacts of trade policy, economic integration, customs unions and free trade areas, international factor movements, and multinational corporations.
